Topic.Title: Intel Buy Back effect in Analyst sentiment

Message.Msg: The Lehman agreement indicated a discounted volume weighted average price computed over a 3-week period (Sept 2 thru 26, 2008 and deliver shares on Sept 29). This was about 50mil shares at the approximate share price at the time. There is a log of room for abuse in these contracts. The two sides of the house are supposed to be isolated but their is a big temptation to cheat. "Under the terms of the 2008 contract, we prepaid $1.0 billion to LOTC, in exchange for which LOTC was required to purchase and deliver to us the number of shares of Intel common stock that could be purchased for $1.0 billion at the discounted volume-weighted average price specified in the contract for the period September 2, 2008 to September 26, 2008."

Message.Title: Technicals all point to a pop for INTC
Message.Msg: unfortunately, some show a pop up and some show a pop down. RSI and MACD show pop up. Fast Stochastic and Williams show pop down. BBands just say there is going to be a pop. You can check technicals yourself with Yahoo graphing. I've never solely relied on technicals. I like to look forward with products, blah blah, and blah blah. I like to look forward. INTC is going to pop. No one on this board is arguing the pop. No one can deny the fabrication advantage. Now for the question: After the party (Taipei and WWDC), what will the hangover be until back-to-school and Christmas? INTC will have an old school Q3 and Q4, leading the technology stocks up. Nowadays, you can add Q1 2014 because of the Chinese New Year holiday. Let's say INTC pops to $28 by end of WWDC (big, I know). From June 17th to August 5th (Independence Day Sales to the beginning of Back-to-School), where do we drift back down to? $24 to $28 back down to ?? until the real run up in Q3, Q4, and Q1 '14.

Message.Title: Derivatives quickly changing in US markets
Message.Msg: Look at the tell signs on both the NASDAQ/NYSE. What is happening is stagnation in the major indices. This happens when the large derivative players are shifting their positions. They are now moving money and are going to bet against both markets. In the past this is when large corrections take place (over 10 percent). The large derivative players are the ones that run the indices. For example look at Warren Buffet; he is a heavy derivative player that has, over the last five years, substantially decreased his position in stocks and gone the derivative route. Smart, rich player. Derivative are an easy way to hide money.......so large losses can be covered up. The SEC does not understand this and they cannot track this. The result is no regulation. It will only take one major, dishonest derivative player to send our financial systems into ruin.

Topic.Title: Derivatives quickly changing in US markets

Message.Msg: The writing is on the wall, you just have to know how to read.

Topic.Title: Acer $400 'PC' will run Android, pack Intel's Haswell chip

Message.Msg: The underlying message here is that Intel x86 runs all OSs and it makes sense for vendors to have Intel's x86 the centerpiece of their designs. As far as "PC" functionality goes Ubuntu Touch or other Linux flavors are probably a better choice than Android but that's the point. Intel's x86 gives user's the choice which OS they run. I find the dual boot Windows/*nix combination most compelling because there are times when you need perfect compatibility with that Windows app on your desktop or notebook.

Message.Title: Why would a company have an ARM division when INTC runs Android and Windows?
Message.Msg: Going forward, it doesn't make sense.

Topic.Title: Derivatives quickly changing in US markets

Topic.Title: Why would a company have an ARM division when INTC runs Android and Windows?

Message.Msg: That is a good question. Any company that makes a tablet expected to sell above the $200 price point will likely have a Windows tablet offering. Once they've built this device it offers greater economy of scale to use Core or Atom for everything else they make because Android, Tizen, Ubuntu or every other Linux variant comes for free, plus the dual-boot option is very compelling. The case for Intel tablets becomes even stronger when Intel Core and Atom also perform better and offer longer battery life. Going forward the business case for ARM becomes much more difficult for anything more than low cost devices with very limited flexibility.

Message.Title: Acer and Asus are planning for massive growth of Haswell based tablets/computers. Win and Android
Message.Msg: At Computex 2013, Acer will showcase two Windows 8 tablets, the 8-inch W3 810 and 11.6-inch Bulgari, while Asustek Computer reportedly will display its new Zenbooks featuring reinforced glass chassis, according to sources with Taiwan-based supply chain makers, The 11.6-inch Bulgari reportedly will adopt an Intel Haswell Core i3 processor and 64GB storage with a resolution up to 2560 by 1440, while Asustek will offer two display sizes - 11- and 13-inch - for its new Zenbooks. With the two new Windows 8 tablets plus the 7.9-inch Iconia A1 and the upcoming 10-inch Android-based entry-level model, Acer is expected to have no trouble achieving its shipment goal of 10 million tablets in 2013, the sources said. Acer will have Android and Windows 8 models account for 75% and 25%, of its tablet shipments, the sources added. The sources also noted that the touchscreen function is already believed by brand vendors to be the major driver of their profits and sales in 2013. For Acer, touchscreen models already accounted for 12% of its total notebook shipments in the first quarter and the percentage is expected to rise to 20% in the second quarter, 50% for the entire 2014 and 70% in 2015. Meanwhile, Asustek's touchscreen notebooks already had a shipment proportion of almost 25% in the first quarter, a lot higher than the 10% of the market average. The percentage is estimated to reach 25% in the second quarter and higher in the second half of 2013. Currently, Asustek has a 30-35% share in the global touchscreen notebook market.

Message.Title: Global tablet shipments to grow 62% in 2013, says MIC. The PC is not dead, the traditional laptop is, imho.
Message.Msg: There will be 182 million notebooks shipped globally in 2013, decreasing 5.3% on year, while tablet shipments will increase 62.2% to 228 million, according to the Market Intelligence & Consulting Institute (MIC) under the government-sponsored Institute for Information Industry. China-based white-box vendors will be the main source of the growth in tablet shipments, with most of their tablets produced by China-based ODM/OEMs, MIC indicated.

Topic.Title: Any news from Romit/James Covello ??

Message.Msg: Romit Shah did his pre-Intel event reiteration and indicated that Apple and Intel may not be able to work a foundry agreement. Romit's assessment: "this can't be good". Romit's target has been $18 and I have not seen him drop it. Covello is the only analyst below $18 that I know of. Nothing yet from Covello and his $16 target. He might be waiting for Haswell and its "apparent success" to back track on his low target. StreetInsider "A rumored deal between Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) and Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) is "less certain," according Nomura analyst Romit Shah. Information cited by Nomura claims the two sides may have disagreements over price." "While speculation about Intel-Apple partnership remains ongoing, our research suggests that a deal has recently become less certain," said Shah. "While we have not gotten a definitive explanation why negotiations with Intel could have stalled, we believe cost could be a key factor. Our understanding is that Samsung could be pricing wafers 20-30% below Intel. As such, we see TSMC (NYSE: TSM) manufacturing Apple's A7/A7X chips in 2013 and 2014 and Samsung at this point on track to manufacture Apple's A8x chips in 2015." Nomura Securities has a Reduce rating on Intel with a price target of $18.00.

Message.Title: Cell phone carriers bill for hardware
Message.Msg: The byproduct of ARM not really coming out with new hardware that excites consumers is the pricing pressure put on carriers by consumers. Carriers are now pushing low rates to steal business from each other. The hardware is out of the equation. The deal is, if you require new hardware they have $20 a month classic lease systems. If after a few months you decide to drop the carrier, you'll get a bill for the remaining balance on the phone which could be anywhere between $400 to $600. This is the European market model which will come to the United States. Essentially you buy your hardware and shop for service. This is going to affect demand of new hardware. I know the ARM fans are quick to point out benchmarks. But will consumers fork over top dollar for top hardware? Or will the second hand market grow? Though, you'll be surprised how much older smartphones are commanding. Keep in mind Intel still has specs for $175 smartphones. It must be maddening for tier one handset suppliers. Dropping demand from consumers and the potential of Intel being a loose canon in the market by pushing private labels carrier phones. The ARM fans really believe Intel may be locked out of the Tier 1 market. I wouldn't be so certain.

Message.Title: Intel's Haswell launch may take backseat to Atom vs. ARM
Message.Msg: Intel is widely expected to launch its latest PC processors at Computex, which will outline an array of new Windows 8 devices, but the real game may revolve around Atom's future roadmap and mobility. Naysayers will note that the chip giant's prospects against the ARM architecture aren't good. These naysayers are also likely to add that Intel's Haswell-based chips are designed for a PC industry that is getting thumped by tablets. The argument against Intel goes like this: 1.ARM, a low power processor architecture, will dominate as mobile computing (smartphones and tablets) routs PC sales in the years ahead. 2.Intel's manufacturing prowess and focus on performance is a waste in an era of good enough computing. 3.Intel doesn't seem to have a mobile answer that's been given a thumbs up by the market. 4.New Intel CEO Brian Krzanich is likely to stay the course so the chip giant may never solve for ARM. Folks following the semiconductor industry can recite those arguments in their sleep. To many folks, Qualcomm is the new Intel. Of course, Intel begs to differ with that opinion. Now there's an increasingly vocal chorus of analysts who believe that Intel can solve for ARM and ultimately pass that architecture in mobile computing. In other words, Intel's recent design wins with Samsung and Asus at ARM's expense are just the beginning. These analysts are largely backing Intel based on the company's next-gen Atom roadmap dubbed Silvermont. Intel presented its roadmap earlier this month and plans to improve Atom every year. Silvermont will have a burst frequency to handle various use cases.

Message.Title: RBC says Samsung could be "tip of the iceberg." Outperform rating with target of $29
Message.Msg: This morning it was reported that an upcoming Galaxy Tablet by Samsung will feature a processor built by Intel (Nasdaq: INTC). The win is a blow to ARM Holdings plc (Nasdaq: ARMH), which usually powers Android devices. The news is providing bulls with new ammunition, and some say this could be the tip of the iceberg for Intel's growing mobile presence. Checks by RBC suggest further traction in mobile is on the way, a realization that could catch many investors by surprise. Commenting, analyst Doug Freedman said, "The data point is in support of our thesis that Intel's mobile presence, which is currently being discounted in the marketplace, will become increasing visible on 32nm Clover Trail+, ahead of its move to leading-edge 14nm in 2014. We highlight this is particularly encouraging given that we expect Bay Trail 22nm to be more significant than Clover Trail+ based on its performance lead." "Even marginal upside from handset revenues should push the applied multiple higher, as it shows that Intel's bet on x86 against ARM is finally making in-roads," added the analyst. RBC has an Outperform rating on Intel with a price target of $29.

Topic.Title: RBC says Samsung could be "tip of the iceberg." Outperform rating with target of $29

Message.Msg: I am impressed with RBC. After Netflix released "House of Cards", RBC sent someone to interview the major Hollywood talent agencies to check the willingness of talent (directors, actors, screenwriters) to work with Netflix on original productions. RBC actually pounds the pavement to get at information beyond the stats everybody can access from a company's press releases. Because this is RBC saying Samsung could be the "tip of the iceberg" it has more weight than normal. It should be taken seriously.

Topic.Title: Intel's Haswell launch may take backseat to Atom vs. ARM

Message.Msg: Except the argument against Intel is factually incorrect. Intel's Clovertrail+ already matches or exceeds the best ARM's shipping on performance and efficiency. Secondly, Bay Trail and Merrifield are vastly better than Clovertrail+ on performance and efficiency and will be even more competitive against ARM. For high-end tablets, Haswell is in a league of its own with nothing challenging it in performance, and all Intel SoC's are capable of running Windows or Android. Intel's manufacturing prowess isn't just about speed, it's also about energy efficiency and being the cost leader for volume chip production. Vendors are way ahead of analysts in understanding the impact to their future. This is why all the major vendors are preparing to release new flagship products featuring Intel's parts.

Message.Title: Intel Corporation (INTC) Emerges as Moore’s Law Victor
Message.Msg: Intel Corporation (INTC) is expected to emerge as one of the few survivors of the ruthless implementation of Moore’s Law in the semiconductor industry, monetizing its manufacturing capabilities with its own product and also engaging in foundry partnerships with fabless companies, says John Pitzer, Managing Director, Global Technology Strategist and Analyst at Credit Suisse Group. “It’s our view that Intel will be the last man standing on Moore’s Law. Before they are right, they will find multiple ways in which to monetize that in their core business by bringing out incremental performance that people will pay for, and in the nontraditional markets of tablets and smartphones by getting down their cost points and performance points that other people won’t be able to match,” Pitzer said. FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THIS INTERVIEW CLICK HERE. Intel further monetizes its advanced semiconductor manufacturing capabilities by partnering with other companies in foundry partnerships. Its leadership in this segment, Pitzer says, is expected to result in the world gathering at its factories for advanced chips. “What you are seeing is Intel‘s manufacturing lead is stretching out, but Intel is now signing up foundry partners. The most public one was Altera (ALTR) about a month and a half ago who has historically been a customer at TSM. Altera has decided to use Intel because they have a better manufacturing process. We think Cisco (CSCO) will also start to build chips at Intel, as well as Apple (AAPL). This is all based upon this view that Intel will be the last man standing on Moore’s Law. They will continue to stretch out their manufacturing lead, and the world will be forced to be on the path to their door,” Pitzer said. From twst

Topic.Title: Big Intel/Samsung Press

Message.Msg: Samsung knows they won't be able to compete against Intel - comment picked up from EE times. Nothing really "new" but the analysts are slow to comprehend - the ARM FinFet is a hoax. The ARM foundries can compete with each other but they won't be able to compete with Intel. I am fairly confident that Apple decided a couple years ago to go with TSMC @ 20nm - and they stuck with it and they probably regretting it. Sentiment towards Intel SoC capabilities has changed dramatically compared to two years ago.. G61 does not post here anymore - sometimes he sounded like Romit or Gus - always talked about the architecture and that Intel should fab ARM chips ...well he's gone R.I.P. Even if they get it right the "real" shocker is really the increasing cost - No more cheap ARM SoC 5/31/2013 11:06 AM EDT Yes 16 node is really 20 node transistor density (both transistor pitch and metal pitch are same as 20) at higher wafer cost. It makes no sense. Cost per transistor goes up (Moore's law goes backward) Plus if that was not bad enough it is too costly to build and validate design IP for 2 nodes with the same transistor density. This is why Altera, Cisco, Micro Semi and i hear likely another another left for intel. Intel''s 14 nm will have a real 14nm metal system and a real 14nm transistor density

This is the game the Wall Street big guys play. And they are ready to look/sound idiots a timesif that helps them win the game.

Message.Title: Samsung having serious problems with "big-little"
Message.Msg: SAMMOBILE Posted by MartinR on 30 May 2013 at 18:09 Samsung’s processor chaos affects Mobile divisions processor choice "We have information from several sources that Exynos’s CCI is inherently crippled in silicon. It is not functional or even powered on in the shipping product (i9500). In fact, this has been such of an issue, that as a result, the chip was almost cancelled. It was reportedly only salvaged by having it work in the cluster migration policy and bypass the CCI entirely. While contradicting, it questions the validity of ARM’s own videos while demonstrating the Octa. Internally at SLSI, as many as three projects were cancelled late last year. We don’t know the reasons for their cancellation, however it is said that the issues are related, and unacceptable power consumption also plays a big role. One can argue that ARM’s Cortex A15 is partly to blame here: The inherent architecture is to power consuming to be implemented in a smart-phone. big.LITTLE provides major breathing-room, but only in scenarios where continuous load is not an issue. HD gaming is a major Achilles heel where power consumption can run rampant. Nvidia is having it much worse with their Tegra 4: With only a single tablet design win besides their own Shield gaming console, it’s a chip that needs to, and will be, quickly forgotten. Plagued by delays, hardware bugs, and high power consumption, one could view the Exynos 5410 as nothing short of a failure. In fact, Samsung’s Mobile division was so dismayed at the whole situation that their next major products will completely forego the company’s own Exynos chips and go straight with Qualcomm’s offerings. Reports that the Note 3 would come with the S800 match with this information, and are probably very correct." Much more at; sammobileDOTcom/2013/05/30/samsung-processor-chaos-disappointments-and-their-current-soc-future/

Topic.Title: Samsung having serious problems with "big-little"

Message.Msg: continued; "As for SLSI, things look very bleak for Samsung’s in-house processors. The business is failing to cater, not only in terms of support, like providing proper hardware documentation and source code to the public, but the current line-up is in shambles also in terms of hardware. Lackluster graphics performance and outdated GPUs have become sort of a habit for the company. This reportedly is due to an unwillingness to spend the money on IP licenses from third-party companies, and the use of Mali GPUs in their SoCs is due to a free licensing agreement they receive from ARM as a lead partner. The surprise use of the SGX 544MP3 in the Exynos 5410 is due to panic caused by Mali’s own T6xx GPUs: again an issue of extremely excessive power consumption. The first generation Midgard lineup was quickly scrapped, leaving the Exynos 5250 and its T604 as something of an orphan. Products like the T658 never saw the light of day and are not even mentioned anymore on ARM’s website. Meanwhile, while their shipping products are failing to properly compete, Samsung is spending a lot of money on developing their own GPU IP from scratch. Not much information is available as to when we will see this in actual products, but it will eventually come, if not cancelled or delayed due to its unorthodox implementation of an FPGA-like re-programmable design which might be hit-or-miss. Imagination’s Rogue architecture and years of experience as a leading GPU IP provider will be tough competition. CPU wise, things look just as bleak. Qualcomm currently dominates the performance per Watt scale for the high-end with the newest Krait architectures. With no custom design in the works, as done by Apple or Qualcomm, and no A57 or A53 as architectural refreshes from ARM, nor a new 20nm manufacturing process coming until 2014, the Exynos A15 line-up looks incapable of competing in the near-future. The above is written by a guest writer, a current respected and knowledgeable developer "
